answers.answer: Oh, Lordy.  Hi, Linda, Long time no see.I think your advanced age is working against you in this report.  How does it feel to be one of the elderly?You have bilateral lesions, which in this part of the report are not characterized as to location, enhancement or size.  Were they described better in the section above the summary?I gather the cervical MRI was clear?The radiologist threw in the whole realm of possible solutions leading with those diseases that are caused by vascular problems.  The first is "old, microangiopathic disease".  This includes the lesions caused by uncontrolled high blood pressure (has this been a problem?), diabetes, migraines, ????plain ole' headaches (that's a new one), a bout of encephalitis (surely you would know if you had that.  You always end up hospitalized - or should have.  And finally he lists demyelinating process, the most common of which is MS.Yes, the first category would include many ministrokes.  But, more it refers to the generally assymptomatic damage that high blood pressure causes in the brain.Can you rule out hypertension, diabetes, migraine disease or a previous bout of encephalitis (like West Nile)?I don't remember your history of symptoms (sorry).  Can you point us toward a review of what all has happened to you so it can be put into context with your MRI like your neuro should do?Quix

Hi Quix,  that I know of my blood pressure is fine, no diabetes, or any thing other than Ms.Here is the whole report: this is only the brain report. Technique multi planar T1 T 2- weighted images of the brain performed prior to and following the uneventful administrationOf gadolinium contrast.The corpus callosum,pitutiary fossa, pineal region,posterior fossa, and cervical medullary junction are normal.No diffusion weighted abnormality is present to suggest an acute infarction.The ventricles and sulci are normal in size. There are scattered numerous foci of T2 signal abnormality involving the subcortial white matter primarily in but also some periventricular white matter, nonspecific in nature.No definate brainstem or posterior fossa lesions are seen.No inter cranial hemorrhage or extra-axial fluid collection is identified.No pathological enhancement is noted following gadolinium contrast administration.The calvarium is un remarkable.Impression as above.  thanks Quix your the best

question: I had Mri brain and cervical thursday. Impression Nonspecific white matter signal abnormality bilaterally.Differential considerations are broad and include old microangiopathic ischemic disease migraine headaches, headaches,post infectious/post inflammatory process,or a demylinating process. can  anyone translate. Stroke? Thanks in advance Linda
title: Results
